n.c: Evaluation Details: This course has no final test. However, students will be administered two discussion tests during the semester: one in the first half related to group projects and another in the second half related to individual projects. Each test is worth 10%.

Evaluation Details: During the semester, students will need to complete two written reports (each worth 15%) based on in-class discussions and presentations: one for the group project and another for the individual project.

Evaluation Details: Twice during the semester, students will need to make oral presentations of findings obtained first through a group research project and then through an individual research project. Each presentation is worth 20% of the final grade. In addition, students will regularly be evaluated on their contributions to discussion and problem-solving tasks assigned in class. This component is worth 10% of the final grade.

Other Requirements Relating to Evaluation  Attendance Policy Students must attend at least two-thirds of the sessions, or they will receive an ‘F' for their final grade.  Homework and Participation Students are expected to complete an average of 90 minutes of homework each week to achieve a passing grade in this class. The homework will include written assignments, undertaking Internet- and library-based research, collecting experimental data, and preparing presentations.

Evaluation Details: During the semester, students will need to complete two written reports (each worth 15%) based on in-class discussions and presentations: one for the group project and another for the individual project.

Evaluation Details: Twice during the semester, students will need to make oral presentations of findings obtained first through a group research project and then through an individual research project. Each presentation is worth 20% of the final grade. In addition, students will regularly be evaluated on their contributions to discussion and problem-solving tasks assigned in class. This component is worth 10% of the final grade.

Other Requirements Relating to Evaluation  Attendance Policy Students must attend at least two-thirds of the sessions, or they will receive an ‘F' for their final grade.  Homework and Participation Students are expected to complete an average of 90 minutes of homework each week to achieve a passing grade in this class. The homework will include written assignments, undertaking Internet- and library-based research, collecting experimental data, and preparing presentations.

c: コンピュータグラフィクス

n.c: 第1回:レイトレーシング法が表現できる現象について正しく理解し、現実の風景と対比して説明できること。  第2回:CSGモデルによる形状設計を正しく理解し、実際に設計できること。  第3回:VRを中心とする技術の発展と社会との関係について、過去、現在、近未来について適切に調査・考察できること。  第4回:XRシステムの体験・視聴を通じて、授業で得た知識と関連付けて考察できること。    各回の「採点のめやす」は出題時に履修生に開示する。
各回の講義後に行う小問題(小テスト)にて、講義内容に関して正しく理解の上、説明・計算できること。  これらには映像視聴を踏まえた問題を含むため、欠席した学生は解答できず、代替措置を取り得ないことを予め承知すること。

出席、質疑応答など

試験,レポート,平常点評価の割合は上記を基本とするが,履修者の理解度を踏まえ総合的に判断する.

実習内容と結果を適切に説明できていれば基準点とし,さらに独自で調査・実験を行いその内容が適切であれば追加得点とする.実習レポートは全て提出する必要がある。
講義中に行う演習により評価する.
試験,レポート,平常点評価の割合は上記を基本とするが,履修者の理解度を踏まえ総合的に判断する.

n.c: Evaluation Details: This course has no final test. However, students will be administered two discussion tests during the semester: one in the first half related to group projects and another in the second half related to individual projects. Each test is worth 10%.

Evaluation Details: During the semester, students will need to complete two written reports (each worth 15%) based on in-class discussions and presentations: one for the group project and another for the individual project.

Evaluation Details: Twice during the semester, students will need to make oral presentations of findings obtained first through a group research project and then through an individual research project. Each presentation is worth 20% of the final grade. In addition, students will regularly be evaluated on their contributions to discussion and problem-solving tasks assigned in class. This component is worth 10% of the final grade.

Other Requirements Relating to Evaluation  Attendance Policy Students must attend at least two-thirds of the sessions, or they will receive an ‘F' for their final grade.  Homework and Participation Students are expected to complete an average of 90 minutes of homework each week to achieve a passing grade in this class. The homework will include written assignments, undertaking Internet- and library-based research, collecting experimental data, and preparing presentations.

Evaluation Details: During the semester, students will need to complete two written reports (each worth 15%) based on in-class discussions and presentations: one for the group project and another for the individual project.

Evaluation Details: Twice during the semester, students will need to make oral presentations of findings obtained first through a group research project and then through an individual research project. Each presentation is worth 20% of the final grade. In addition, students will regularly be evaluated on their contributions to discussion and problem-solving tasks assigned in class. This component is worth 10% of the final grade.

Other Requirements Relating to Evaluation  Attendance Policy Students must attend at least two-thirds of the sessions, or they will receive an ‘F' for their final grade.  Homework and Participation Students are expected to complete an average of 90 minutes of homework each week to achieve a passing grade in this class. The homework will include written assignments, undertaking Internet- and library-based research, collecting experimental data, and preparing presentations.

n.c: There will be one in-class exam which assesses the students' knowledge and comprehension of Marx, Durkheim, and Weber.

There will be one short writing exercise (15%) and one long paper assignment (30%). For the writing exercise, students will respond to an essay question provided by the instructor. For the paper assignment, students will write on a topic of their choice selected in consultation with the instructor. The paper should make use of the concepts and ideas of at least two thinkers encountered in the semester, and they should be applied to some aspect of the social world. The purpose is to have students get acquainted with making a theoretically-informed argument.

n.c: Evaluation Details: This course has no final test. However, students will be administered two discussion tests during the semester: one in the first half related to group projects and another in the second half related to individual projects. Each test is worth 10%.

Evaluation Details: During the semester, students will need to complete two written reports (each worth 15%) based on in-class discussions and presentations: one for the group project and another for the individual project.

Evaluation Details: Twice during the semester, students will need to make oral presentations of findings obtained first through a group research project and then through an individual research project. Each presentation is worth 20% of the final grade. In addition, students will regularly be evaluated on their contributions to discussion and problem-solving tasks assigned in class. This component is worth 10% of the final grade.

Other Requirements Relating to Evaluation  Attendance Policy Students must attend at least two-thirds of the sessions, or they will receive an ‘F' for their final grade.  Homework and Participation Students are expected to complete an average of 90 minutes of homework each week to achieve a passing grade in this class. The homework will include written assignments, undertaking Internet- and library-based research, collecting experimental data, and preparing presentations.

n.c: Evaluation Details: This course has no final test. However, students will be administered two discussion tests during the semester: one in the first half related to group projects and another in the second half related to individual projects. Each test is worth 10%.

Evaluation Details: During the semester, students will need to complete two written reports (each worth 15%) based on in-class discussions and presentations: one for the group project and another for the individual project.

Evaluation Details: Twice during the semester, students will need to make oral presentations of findings obtained first through a group research project and then through an individual research project. Each presentation is worth 20% of the final grade. In addition, students will regularly be evaluated on their contributions to discussion and problem-solving tasks assigned in class. This component is worth 10% of the final grade.

Other Requirements Relating to Evaluation  Attendance Policy Students must attend at least two-thirds of the sessions, or they will receive an ‘F' for their final grade.  Homework and Participation Students are expected to complete an average of 90 minutes of homework each week to achieve a passing grade in this class. The homework will include written assignments, undertaking Internet- and library-based research, collecting experimental data, and preparing presentations.

n.c: Evaluation Details: This course has no final test. However, students will be administered two tests during the semester: a Mid-term Discussion Test worth 20%, and an Internet Research and Source Acknowledgement Quiz worth 10%.
Evaluation Details: During the semester, students will need to complete four written assignments (each worth 10%) based on in-class discussions and one final report (worth 15%).

Evaluation Details: Toward the end of the semester, students will need to make an oral presentation of findings obtained through a group project. Although the presentations will be done in small groups, grading will be based on each individual student's contributions to the presentation. This assessment component is worth 15% of the final grade.

Other Requirements Relating to Evaluation  1. Attendance Policy Students must attend at least two-thirds of the sessions, or they will receive an ‘F' for their final grade.  2. Homework and Participation Students are expected to complete an average of 100 minutes of homework each week to achieve a passing grade in this class. The homework will include written assignments, undertaking Internet- and library-based research, and preparing presentations.

n.c: 以下のことに対してレポートを作成する。A4レポート用紙3~5枚(修士)、2~3枚(学部学生)。自分の考えのない研究内容の調査のみではレポートとして認められない可能性もある。絵や図を使っても構いませんが、他の論文や記事の図を使うときは、必ず引用先を明示すること。  1MEMS関連の研究テーマにて、国際会議論文、英語論文・国内外のweb等を用いて調査し、新たなシステム(例、新たなものを測るマイクロセンサ、新たな組み合わせのシステム、新たな使用方法)を提案して、その特徴・利点・実現方法・社会での利用可能性について説明をしてください。  皆さんが思うこんなのがあったら良いな、こういうのができたら良いなというのを自由に上げて、どうしたらできるのか、実際にできたら社会にどんな影響をもたらすのかを授業を参考にしながら考えてみましょう。  2授業の感想、改善点など自由記載

n.c: Evaluation Details: This course has no final test. However, students will be administered two tests during the semester: a Mid-term Discussion Test worth 20%, and an Internet Research and Source Acknowledgement Quiz worth 10%.
Evaluation Details: During the semester, students will need to complete four written assignments (each worth 10%) based on in-class discussions and one final report (worth 15%).

Evaluation Details: Toward the end of the semester, students will need to make an oral presentation of findings obtained through a group project. Although the presentations will be done in small groups, grading will be based on each individual student's contributions to the presentation. This assessment component is worth 15% of the final grade.

Other Requirements Relating to Evaluation  1. Attendance Policy Students must attend at least two-thirds of the sessions, or they will receive an ‘F' for their final grade.  2. Homework and Participation Students are expected to complete an average of 100 minutes of homework each week to achieve a passing grade in this class. The homework will include written assignments, undertaking Internet- and library-based research, and preparing presentations.

理解度をはかるため数回のレポート課題の提出を求める。全ての回のレポートを提出することで評価する。
毎回の授業では授業時間内にミニ課題を提示し、その場で取り組み解答を提出することで出席として扱う。解説も授業時間内に行う。  ミニ課題は評価基準には含まないが、授業の聴講が2/3以上が必須(規定回数以上のミニ課題の提出がなければ全レポートが提出され、試験を受けていても評価対象外とする)。
病気や怪我その他正当な理由で、試験を欠席、レポート提出が遅れたりする場合は担当教員に相談のこと。

n.c: Evaluation Details: This course has no final test. However, students will be administered two discussion tests during the semester: one in the first half related to group projects and another in the second half related to individual projects. Each test is worth 10%.

Evaluation Details: During the semester, students will need to complete two written reports (each worth 15%) based on in-class discussions and presentations: one for the group project and another for the individual project.

Evaluation Details: Twice during the semester, students will need to make oral presentations of findings obtained first through a group research project and then through an individual research project. Each presentation is worth 20% of the final grade. In addition, students will regularly be evaluated on their contributions to discussion and problem-solving tasks assigned in class. This component is worth 10% of the final grade.

Other Requirements Relating to Evaluation  Attendance Policy Students must attend at least two-thirds of the sessions, or they will receive an ‘F' for their final grade.  Homework and Participation Students are expected to complete an average of 90 minutes of homework each week to achieve a passing grade in this class. The homework will include written assignments, undertaking Internet- and library-based research, collecting experimental data, and preparing presentations.

n.c: 第14週目に期末テストを実施して、理解度確認を行います。原則、再試験は行いません。
毎回の授業開始時に出席をとりますが、出席しただけでは評価としません。また、毎回の授業の理解度確認(一部は、次回の予習を含む)のために、Waseda Moodleを通じて課題を提出してもらいます。配布した紙に解答し、それをJPEGファイルかPDFとしてアップしてもらい、課題を採点して平常点評価とします。ただし、授業に出席せずに提出だけの場合は5割採点とします。
小テスト1(分岐アルカン命名法に関するオンラインテスト:10%)、小テスト2(官能基を有する有機化合物命名法に関するオンラインテスト:10%)を実施して、理解度確認を行います。原則、再試験は行いません。
